DataElement.preferredName: Stomach Cancer Additional Pathologic Findings Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Text term that represents significant pathologic finding present in a patient with stomach cancer.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A malignant epithelial tumor of the stomach mucosa. The vast majority of gastric carcinomas are adenocarcinomas, arising from the gastric glandular epithelium._Added; extra; further._Caused by or altered by or manifesting disease or pathology._Clinical, laboratory or molecular evidence, or absence of evidence of disease.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A malignant epithelial tumor of the stomach mucosa. The vast majority of gastric carcinomas are adenocarcinomas, arising from the gastric glandular epithelium.

Concepts.definition: A malignant epithelial tumor of the stomach mucosa. The vast majority of gastric carcinomas are adenocarcinomas, arising from the gastric glandular epithelium.

Property.preferredDefinition: Added; extra; further.:Caused by or altered by or manifesting disease or pathology.:Clinical, laboratory or molecular evidence, or absence of evidence of disease.

Concepts.definition: Caused by or altered by or manifesting disease or pathology.
Clinical, laboratory or molecular evidence, or absence of evidence of disease.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Specification of human conditions relevant to cancer. This includes observations, test results, history, and other concepts relevant to characterization of human cancer-related conditions. Non-neoplastic conditions of interest are also included.

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: Created for Stomach cancer request 4.19.18 mc

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A usually exophytic mass attached to the underlying tissue by a broad base or a thin stalk.  Polyps can be neoplastic or non-neoplastic.  Neoplastic polyps usually represent proliferations of the epithelium, and are commonly seen in the gastrointestinal tract.  Polyps of the gastrointestinal tract are often called adenomas, are associated with dysplasia, and may eventually transform into carcinomas.  Non-neoplastic polyps may be inflammatory, degenerative, or the result of malformations. -- 2004

Concepts.definition: A usually exophytic mass attached to the underlying tissue by a broad base or a thin stalk.  Polyps can be neoplastic or non-neoplastic.  Neoplastic polyps usually represent proliferations of the epithelium, and are commonly seen in the gastrointestinal tract.  Polyps of the gastrointestinal tract are often called adenomas, are associated with dysplasia, and may eventually transform into carcinomas.  Non-neoplastic polyps may be inflammatory, degenerative, or the result of malformations.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Pertaining to autoimmunity.: A condition in which the stomach muscles shrink and become weak. The digestive (peptic) glands may also shrink, resulting in a lack of digestive juices.

Concepts.definition: Atrophic gastritis that is persistent and long-standing.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Inflammation of the stomach that is associated with Helicobacter Pylori.

Concepts.definition: Inflammation of the stomach that is associated with Helicobacter Pylori.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Used to describe tumor samples that exhibit poorly differentiated or undifferentiated cells. They are generally expected to be fast growing and aggressive.: A usually neoplastic transformation of the cell, associated with altered architectural tissue patterns. The cellular changes include nuclear and cytoplasmic abnormalities. Molecular genetic abnormalities are also often found and, in some instances, may lead to cancer.

Concepts.definition: Used to describe tumor samples that exhibit poorly differentiated or undifferentiated cells. They are generally expected to be fast growing and aggressive.

A usually neoplastic transformation of the cell, associated with altered architectural tissue patterns. The cellular changes include nuclear and cytoplasmic abnormalities. Molecular genetic abnormalities are also often found and, in some instances, may lead to cancer.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: denoting slow growth; indolent.: A usually neoplastic transformation of the cell, associated with altered architectural tissue patterns.  The cellular changes include nuclear and cytoplasmic abnormalities.  Molecular genetic abnormalities are also often found and, in some instances, may lead to cancer. -- 2004

Concepts.definition: Used to describe tumor samples that exhibit well to moderately well differentiated cells. They are generally expected to be slow growing and less aggressive.

A usually neoplastic transformation of the cell, associated with altered architectural tissue patterns. The cellular changes include nuclear and cytoplasmic abnormalities. Molecular genetic abnormalities are also often found and, in some instances, may lead to cancer.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A morphologic finding indicating the replacement of epithelial tissue outside the intestines by intestinal-type epithelium.

Concepts.definition: A morphologic finding indicating the replacement of epithelial tissue outside the intestines by intestinal-type epithelium.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: No person or thing, nobody, not any.: The procedure of having an identity established.

Concepts.definition: No person or thing, nobody, not any.
The procedure of having an identity established.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Specification of human conditions relevant to cancer. This includes observations, test results, history, and other concepts relevant to characterization of human cancer-related conditions. Non-neoplastic conditions of interest are also included.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

Concepts.definition: Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.
